textContent:
I have been completely focused on staying together, without ever really considering separation as an option. The focus on staying together has been so pervasive that it's distorted reality, causing me to continually fail to acknowledge what's actually happening, and instead double down on trying to fix things. This reflection is not a decision but an exploration of our feelings and options to understand our path forward better.

Why have I been so focused on us staying no matter what? Because our marriage vow is to stick it out through thick and thin, better or worse. I don't want to believe that what might be better for you, or better for me, is separation. Yet, I can't deny that when I put the reasons down on paper for the first time, reasons for staying are mostly based on fear and the reasons for separating are mostly based on hope. To hope is to love. To love is to let go, release control, and be open to what emerges, even when it breaks my heart open. In breaking my heart open, may it remain open and radiate all the abundant love, compassion, empathy, patience, and joy it can into the world, creating the strength I need to love myself and love you in the ways we both need.

Why Should We Stay? 
- I love Gil and will always love Gil
- Gil loves me and will always love me
- I don't want to lose Gil in my life
- I don't want to cause Gil pain 
- I don't trust Gil can handle the pain (SI)
- I don't want to hurt our kids 
- I don't trust the kids can handle the hurt 
- things are good 
- I'm comfortable
- I should be grateful for what I have
- I'm not sure the future will be better 
- I believe marriage is a commitment for life
- I don't want to disappoint my family
- I want to avoid the pain, shame, hurt 
- It's selfish to choose what's best for me 
- If we stick it out, maybe we will change enough for this to work
- because it's what you do when you're married
- Because I won't have to confront failing Gil, failing my kids, and failing myself. 

Why Should We Seperate?
- I love Gil and will always love Gil
- Gil loves me and will always love me
- Gil can still be a dear friend life
- We can still be in each other's lives
- We have known since the beginning that our differences were challenging & incompatible 
- I'm not lit up by the parts that light her up
- Gil isn't lit up by the parts that light me up 
- We don't light up all of each other's parts
- Gil and I want different lifestyles, focuses
- I trust Gil's capacity to heal
- I trust my capacity to heal 
- Gil needs her own space to learn herself 
- I need my own space to learn myself 
- I trust this will be better for our kids when our kids experience allove from us, when we are our best selves. Only then can we nurture their best selves
- Being in the right soil and conditions will open up opportunities in the future Gil and I can't imagine today, that will continue to nurture and nourish our best selves 

Love is the Answer 
We took a vow to love each other for the rest of our lives and to support each other through thick and thin, good times and bad. Instead of clinging to what is, reality is saying loving each other is creating the space needed to separate our entangled root balls, add more nutrients to the soil, and grow more resilient and strong so we can stand on our own two feet. Love looks like supporting each other in this way, with compassion, patience, gratitude, and hope that we will find a life that lights us up and creates peace and joy. Because only then will we have truly lived into the vows to love each other, in the ways we need to be loved.

No matter what we decide, I want you to know that my love for you is unwavering. This reflection is about understanding our needs and ensuring that our love continues to grow, whether together or apart. I am committed to our well-being and to finding a path that brings us both happiness and fulfillment. We will navigate this journey together, with mutual respect and care, and whatever happens, you will always have a special place in my heart.
